“Ugh, if I don’t fix this shirt tonight, he’ll just make the hole bigger tomorrow,” she said, struggling to breathe. “So, Prince Schegolskoy, a guy from Petersburg, just came by… he danced with me and wanted to propose the next day. I thanked him nicely but told him my heart belongs to someone else. That someone is your dad, Polya; he was super mad about it. 

Is the water ready? Hand me the shirt and the stockings! Lida,” she called to the youngest, “you’ll have to skip the chemise tonight… just lay your stockings out with it. I’ll wash them all together. 

Why hasn’t that drunken loser come back? His shirt looks like a rag! I want to do this all at once, so I don’t have to work two nights in a row! Oh no! (Cough, cough, cough!) Not again! What’s happening?” She noticed a crowd in the hallway, men pushing into her room with something heavy. “What’s going on? What are they bringing? Oh dear!”

“Where should we put him?” asked the policeman, glancing around as they brought in Marmeladov, unconscious and bleeding.

“On the sofa! Lay him down this way,” Raskolnikov directed.

“He got run over! Drunk!” someone yelled from the hallway.

Katerina Ivanovna turned pale and struggled to breathe. The kids were scared. Little Lida screamed, ran to Polenka, and clung to her, shaking all over. After laying Marmeladov down, Raskolnikov rushed to…

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Katerina Ivanovna is distressed as her husband, Marmeladov, is brought home unconscious and injured after being run over by a carriage.
